So now we're going from type inference to type habitation or inhabitation. We're trying to find a term that inhabits this type, okay? So what would be a simple term that would have the type int? Zero, okay, sure. Well, zero is a little specific of an answer. We get back a more general answer that includes zero. In fact, when I worked with Eric Holk and Claire Alvis on this language called Harlan, the original version of Harlan is sort of like a schemely language for GPU programming, but it had like an ML-style type system. And the original type inferencer for that was written in C Canron. And we had to extend these operators to handle different types of numbers. So you can do that.
